Award.AwardTitle: Catalyst Award: Integration of Biotechnology and Cyberinstruction in the Biological Sciences at Fort Valley State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. Through this one-year project, Fort Valley State University seeks to redesign/upgrade its curricula to integrate biotechnology, genomics and cyber-infrastructure [Anywhere, Anytime Learning]. The proposed project will invigorate existing courses by integrating biotechnology applications into the curriculum and pedagogical practices. Cyberinfrastructure and learning will also be infused in laboratory activities, in which bioinformatics tools are used.

The project goal is to redesign and integrate biotechnology and cyberinfrastructure components into core courses, specifically Biotechniques, Cell & Molecular Biology and Genetics. This will provide students with an in-depth understanding of the cycle of scientific problem solving, the nature of iterative experimental design and the role of an adaptive approach that will uniquely prepare them for graduate study or the biotechnology workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The project aim was to implement evidence-based practices in three upper division biology courses. It was accomplished by redesigning the curricula by integrating modern concepts in biotechnology and genomics in both lecture and laboratory components in these courses and supplementing it with cyber instruction to offer “Anywhere, anytime learning experience” to the millennial student population. To further develop student’s scientific communication skills new modules were developed with emphasis on critical analysis of scientific literature and the do’s and do not’s of oral/poster presentations. To enhance the competitiveness of our students for graduate school or STEM workforce we offered mentored research opportunities during academic year and summer, interaction with invited speakers and travel opportunity to attend scientific conferences. Other activities include a seminar series, professional and career development workshops, GRE preparation classes and field trips to various labs.

Broader Impacts: The grant supported enhanced educational experiences for over 200 students in classroom and research labs.  Student presentations at research conferences – ERN, ABRCMS, SOT and Annual Research day at FVSU were instrumental in bolstering student’s confidence and increasing the competitiveness of our graduates in the STEM discipline. Student survey results indicated positive responses to newly developed laboratory exercises. Highlights of student’s achievements in the labs and undergraduate research experience were disseminated in nine articles on FVSU website.
